DOC.HEAD: Report: Group Planned Missile Attacks on European, Arab Planes
With AM-Northwest Flight, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of a pro-Iranian terrorist group arrested in Spain were planning to use surface-to-air missiles to attack Arab and French civilian airliners, a newspaper reported Saturday. The daily Asharq Al-Awsat, in a dispatch from Madrid, quoted unidentified Spanish officials who questioned the suspected terrorists, believed linked to the pro-Iranian group Hezbollah. Spanish police refused to comment on a similar report that appeared Dec. 28 in the Madrid daily Diario. Last month, police discovered a large cache of explosives the suspects allegedly were trying to smuggle into Spain. ``The investigations revealed that Hezbollah planned to use surface-to-air missiles to hit NATO interests in France, as well as passenger planes of Arab and French civil aviation airlines,'' the Saudi Arabian newspaper report said. The time frame of the attacks was not clear, but the Saudi paper said the group planned ``a series of acts of terrorism'' in France in January. The report came at the same time as a bomb threat against a Northwest Airlines flight Saturday from Paris to Detroit. An anonymous telephone caller said the flight was targeted in retaliation for life sentences given to two Palestinians who were convicted in Sweden this month in a series of bombings. One of the Palestinians was Mohammed Abu Talb, a suspect in last year's bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.
